billEvents.eventText: REFERRED TO HOUSING, CONSTRUCTION AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT

title: Provides for correction of all code violations prior to transfer to cooperative or condominium ownership
summary: Requires the sponsor of a plan to convert a building or buildings to cooperative or condominium ownership to cure all serious violations of record of any local or state law with respect to its building and grounds which are the subject of such cooperative or condominium offering.

BILL NUMBER:S2585

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the general business law, in relation to the physical
condition of a building being converted to cooperative or
condominium ownership

PURPOSE/SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
This bill would require a sponsor of a
cooperative or condominium conversion to correct, or' promise to
correct, serious violations of local and state codes concerning
building and housing conditions before the sponsor's conversion plan
could be accepted for filing by the Attorney General.

JUSTIFICATION:
In 1982 the Attorney General
formalized a long-standing
practice by promulgating regulations requiring that an offering plan
for a building undergoing conversion to cooperative or condominium
ownership state that "prior to closing or within a reasonable period
of time thereafter,sponsor will cause to be cured all violations of
record as of the closing date (except violations caused by the acts
or omissions of tenants of the building in their own units) and will
eliminate all dangerous or hazardous conditions that sponsor has
notice of and comply with all work orders from mortgages." 13 NYCRR
SS18.3(hh) (3). These regulations were challenged by sponsors
unwilling to do the work needed to make their buildings safe. A lower
court held by the Attorney General had no authority to promulgate and
enforce the regulations.
COUNCIL FOR OWNER HOUSING, INC. V. ABRAMS, 506 N.Y.S. 2d 1014 (Supreme
Court, Albany County, 1987). An appeal was taken to the Appellate
Division, Third Department, which unanimously affirmed, 125 A. D. 2d
10. On November 22, 1988, the Court of Appeals affirmed the Appellate
Division decision, thus barring the Attorney General from thereafter'
enforcing the regulations. 72 N.Y.2d (1988).

As a result of this decision, sponsors of buildings undergoing
conversion will not be required to correct conditions in such
buildings which have been determined by local building inspectors to
be in violations of law, or which would constitute such violations.
Many of the violations may be dangerous or hazardous to the health
and safety of the prospective purchasers of the cooperative shares or
condominium units (whether resident tenants or outside purchasers),
as well as to non-purchasers tenants who remain there. Furthermore,
the legal obligation to correct such conditions -- and liability for
not doing so -- passes to those purchasers.

This bill will ensure that no conversion in New York City or in
municipalities in Nassau, Rockland or Westchester Counties which have

adopted General Business Law Section 352-e, will be completed, i.e.
title may not be transferred, unless

(1) all serious violations of record and all dangerous or hazardous
conditions that would constitute violations are cured or

(2) the Sponsor has set aside in an escrow account enough money to
Cure all such violations and conditions, or has placed into a reserve
fund an amount in excess of that required by state or local law which
is specifically allocated and adequate to cure all such violations
and conditions.

All sponsors of offering plans which were not declared effective as of
November 22, 1988 are now free to amend their plans to remove their
obligation to Cure violations. Section 3 of this bill clarifies that
all plans which are not yet declared effective would be subject to
its provisions.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect immediately and shall apply to every
offering statement or prospective submitted to the attorney general
on and after such date and to every offering statement or
prospectus submitted to the attorney general which has not yet
been declared effective.
